statement:
**Theorem.** If the real function $f$ is continuous on the interval
$[0,\,\infty)$ and the limit $\displaystyle\lim_{x\to\infty}f(x)$ exists
as a finite number $a$, then $f$ is uniformly continuous on that
interval.\
*Proof.* Let $\varepsilon > 0$. According to the limit condition, there
is a positive number $M$ such that $$\begin{aligned}
|f(x)\!-\!a| \;<\; \frac{\varepsilon}{2} \quad \forall x > M.\end{aligned}$$
The function is continuous on the finite interval $[0,\,M\!+\!1]$; hence
$f$ is also uniformly continuous on this compact interval. Consequently,
there is a positive number $\delta < 1$ such that $$\begin{aligned}
|f(x_1)\!-\!f(x_2)| \;<\; \varepsilon 
\quad \forall\, x_1,\,x_2 \in [0,\,M\!+\!1]\;\;\mbox{with}\;\;|x_1\!-\!x_2| < \delta.\end{aligned}$$
Let $x_1,\,x_2$ be nonnegative numbers and $|x_1\!-\!x_2| < \delta$.
Then $|x_1\!-\!x_2| < 1$ and thus both numbers either belong to
$[0,\,M\!+\!1]$ or are greater than $M$. In the latter case, by (1) we
have $$\begin{aligned}
|f(x_1)\!-\!f(x_2)| \;=\; |f(x_1)\!-\!a\!+\!a\!-\!f(x_2)|\;\leqq\; |f(x_1)\!-\!a|+|f(x_2)\!-\!a| 
\;<\; \frac{\varepsilon}{2}+\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \;=\; \varepsilon.\end{aligned}$$
So, one of the conditions (2) and (3) is always in , whence the
assertion is true.
